RAINY SEASON

Rainy weather vegan Saturday
evening, the first of it passing
around Forest City to the north.

Monday afternoon we had a four
“Frog

hours soaker that filld
Pond” next to Henry Eidam’s store.
Otherwise the rain
has done an

Mrs. lL. Oliver a posteard from
Buffalo, N. Y., with greetings, in-
dicating that he is being transferd
ifrom his training camp in Califor-
nia to France

Henry Hielder and his brother
Allen have made arrangements to
leave today (Thurs.) for the east,
where Allen will seek treatment by

| Harry Oliver writes his mother
|
immense amount of good, not he-|eye specialists in the hope of re-
ing accompanied by any wind

this neighborhood, insuring a big
crop of flax and corn, besides win-
ter pasture.
in covering his eyesight

Numerous honyokers from the
northwestern part of the state are
crossing the river here for the har-
vest fields and other objectives
Wednesday it rained almost the | phey report a light crop in the

whole day thru, the sun being tot-
ally invisible up till five oclock.

West of the river there was a se-
vere hail storm, which blowed
the Episcopal church
Four Bears camp, opposite Le-
Beau, and destroyed several build-
ings at Dupree besides injuring a
couple persons there.

CHANGES AT |
AGENCY

Michael Wolf left for his home
at Reserve, Wisconsin, Monday,
having resignd his position as dis-
ciplinarian. He will be occupied
for a few weeks in puting his busi-
ness affairs in shape and then he
intends to enlist inthe army. Mrs.
Wolf will remain here for a while
pending further arrangements.

Bob Roberts left for Pierre
with the intention of applying for
a position as chaffeur in the army,
having sold most of his personal
property including two automo-
biles.

John Cox has also announced his
intention of resigning, to take
effect about the first of October,
to enter the army service

In addition to the above, it is
said that there will be several other
changes to mark the opening of the
next term of the boarding school.
RIPPLES OF THE RIVER

Mrs. Congdon returnd from Ab-
erdeen Tuesday

Roy Brandon has resignd his po-
sition at the Hospital as janitor.

Mary Gerlach was a visitor at
her home near Laurel over Sunday.
Mrs. Brann, wife of the Gettys-
burg butcher, passed away fast
week

Louis Coon was a visitor at the
Gerlach home near Laurel over
Sunday

‘Sup’t J. H. McGregor went to
Rosebud Agency Monday on offic-
ial business

Harvest is in full blast around
Forest City—except when it rains.
Everybody reports big crops.

Supt. Marble and wife of Crow
Creek Agency were cuests of Supt.
McGregor and family over Sunday.

‘Nelson LeBeau and family were
down from Promise yesterday a¢-
companied by their neighbor Thos.

: Fred LaPlant left for Hot Spngs
the first of the week to take some
baths for a threatend attack of
rheumatism ay

~ Carl H. Hawkinson left for the
training camp at Camp Fremont,
California; Tuesday in company
“with two or three others, entrain-
ing at Gettysburg. _

«Miss Helen Worth and Miss Dor-
othy Donoyan of Cettysbay were
guests of Will Garbe and’ family
over over Sunday. Miss Dorotby is
a niebe of Mrs. Garbe

Mrs. Walter Smith of Gettysbrg
was the guest of Grant Orsborn
and family Sunday. She -expects
to leave within a few weeks for
Seattle, Wash., to visit her daugh-
John Herron of Pierre was in
: the City Saturday evening when he
had the misfortune to break his
and had to remain over _nigtit,

departing for Pierre the following
City a fe
down at

isections they come from
Mr. M. M. Miller of Selby and
ip representative of the Ferry Seed
Co were in town Wednesday morn-
jing. Mr. Miller’s father was engi-
neer of the ferryboat**LizzieReed”
at this point twelve years ago.

Mrs. Welling arrived from Sioux
City according to the expectation
of Bennett Orsborn as noted last
iweek. ‘The following day her hus-
{band was summond to Sioux City
le account of the sickness of his
mother

Forest Gates went to Pierre
| Tuesday with Will Carter and fam-
ily and George Iron Wing. Mrs.
Carter and children concinued
their journey to Rosebud reserva-
ition to visit friends and relatives,
both gentlemen returning with
Forest

—--------4 0 Bp
The dances at Island Park have
become so popular that they are
to be held weekly the balance of

the season, provided the music is
obtainable. This is to announce
another dance for next Sat. evening
Aug. 10th

Company's Certificate of Authority
Whereas, The Mutual Benefit Life In-
surance Company, a corporation organ-

ized under the laws of New Jersey, has
filed in this office a sworn statement
exhibiting its condition and business
for the year ending December 31, 1917,
conformable to the requirements of the

laws of this state regulating the busi-
ness of insurance; and,

Whereas, The said company has filed
in this office a duly certified copy of
its charter; with certificate of organ-
ization, in compliance with the re-
quirements of the insurance law
aforesaid;
Now, therefore, I, W. N. Van Camp,
Commissioner of Insurance of the state
of South Dakota, pursuant to the pro-

visions of said laws, do hereby certify
that the above named company is fully
empowered, through .its authorized
agents, to transact its appropriate
business of Life Insurance in this state,
according to the laws thereof, until the

last day ‘of February, A. D> 1919.
In testimony whereof, I have here-
unto set my hand andé@official seal at
Ferne this first day of March, A. D

W. N. VAN CAMP,
Commissioner of Insurance.
By F. C. MUELLER,
Chief Clerk.

Company’s Certificate of Authority.
Whereas, The Minneapolis Fire &
Marine Insurance Company, a corpora-
tion organized under the laws of Min-
nesota, has filed in thié office a sworn
statement exhibiting its condition and
business for the year énding December
31, 1917, conformable to the require-
ments of the laws of this state regulat-
ing the business of insurance; and,

Whereas, The said cOmpany has filed
in this office a duly certified copy of
its charter; with certificate of organ-
ization, in compliance with the require-
ments of the insurance law aforesaid;
Now, therefore, I, W. N. Van Camp,
Commissioner of Insurance of the state
of South Dakota, pursuant to the pro-
visions of said laws, dod hereby certify
that the above naméd company is
fully empowered, through its author-
ized agents, to transact its appropriate
business of Fire, Tornado, Hail, Marine,
Inland and Sprinkler Leakage Insur-
ance. in this state, atcording to the
laws thereof, until the last day of
February, A. D. 1919.

In testimony whereof, I have here-
unto set my hand and official seal at
EO this first day of March, A. D.

W. N. VAN CAMP,
Commissioner of Insurance.
By F. C. MUELLER,
Chiet Clerk.
